Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Collaborative Research: Finding and Exploiting Hierarchical Structure in Time Series Using Statistical Language Processing Methods

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Applications as diverse as manufacturing, medicine, earth science, finance, and entomology generate massive amounts of temporal or spatio-temporal data. More specifically, information about moving objects, events, and atmospheric measurements that are geo-referenced may be derived from high-resolution satellites, sensors, ground and aerial imagery, GPS, and RFID. Such data present challenges to current approaches for mining time series data. For example, shape-based similarity measures used for classification and clustering consistently fail to produce satisfactory results for long sequences, or trajectories modeling objects that move in 2D or 3D space which may often exhibit similar motion patterns but differ in locations and orientations. In addition, algorithms for finding frequent patterns and anomalies assume known, fixed pattern lengths. This project aims to address the limitations of current approaches to time series data analysis by adapting statistical language processing algorithms and approaches. Specifically, fast algorithms for learning context-free grammars can expose hierarchical structure in time series and thus enable efficient discovery of variable length patterns and facilitate human understanding of time series structure. Also, using the hierarchy to populate a "bag of patterns" can result in significantly more effective similarity measures for long time series, much like the familiar bag of words representation used with documents is effective for a variety of similarity-based language processing tasks on massive corpora.

Given the ubiquitous nature of time series data, advances in algorithms that can help uncover the structure of such data are likely to impact a broad range of applications. All of the results of this research, including publications, algorithms and software, would be made freely available to the broader research and educational community. The project offers enhanced research-based training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students. The project leverages existing programs at George Mason University and the University of Maryland at Baltimore County to to increase the participation of women members of other groups that are under-represented in Computer Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Massive amounts of time series, including spatiotemporal data are generated in fields as diverse as manufacturing, medicine, finance, earth sciences, to name just a few. Scientific and applied advances often depend crucially on finding hierarchical structure and variable-length frequent or anomalous patterns, creating meaningful similarity measures, and facilitating human understanding of massive time series datasets. For example, historical electrocardiogram data could be mined to find patterns common to patients with heart disease, newly emerging unusual patterns for a single patient that signal a change in health state, or complex temporally extended structure that characterizes disease progression. The challenge is to find such structures efficiently and robustly without prior knowledge of their location, number, or length so that the knowledge they convey does not lie forever hidden in the raw data.

The field of statistical natural language processing (SLP) has successfully grappled with many of these issues at scale, producing a wide variety of highly efficient representations, algorithms, and methodologies.  This project exploits this trove of ideas by converting raw time series into sequences of "words", time series "documents", and that are amenable to SLP approaches. Specifically, we proposed time series “bag-of-patterns,” a novel representation inspired by the "bag of words" representation of text documents, leading to powerful new similarity metrics in which global similarity between two sequences is based on their distributional structure of local patterns. Experimental results demonstrated that using distributional information to determine the degree of similarity is a more robust way to characterize and compare data regardless of various types of distortions and noise.

Additionally, we demonstrated that grammar induction, the process of learning rules of a formal language from a set of observations, allows the discovery of hierarchical structures and novel patterns from time series data. More specifically, we proposed efficient algorithms for the discovery of variable-length frequent patterns (motifs) and anomalies in time series using grammar induction. We showed that our algorithms are able to efficiently discover co-existing patterns without any prior knowledge about their length, shape, or minimal occurrence frequency. Furthermore, we developed GrammarViz (http://grammarviz2.github.io/grammarviz2_site/), a software package that provides implementations of proposed algorithms and GUI for interactive variable-length time series pattern discovery.

Other than motif discovery and anomaly detection, grammar induction has applications in other data mining tasks including classification, clustering, and prediction. We proposed a novel algorithm for time series classification based on the discovery of class-specific representative patterns. We define representative patterns of a class as a set of subsequences that has the greatest discriminative power to distinguish one class of time series from another. These representative patterns are selected from an initial pool of common patterns shared by many instances in a class (i.e. class-specific motifs). From this pool of candidate patterns, our algorithm selects the most representative patterns that capture the class specificities, and that can be used to effectively discriminate between time series classes.

In conclusion, our novel techniques bridge the gap between the fields of time series data mining and statistical language processing (SLP), a combination that has not been considered much in the past but has been shown a tremendous promise in our work. Time series data are ubiquitous, so the enhanced ability to gain insight into the structure of data offered by the algorithms developed in this project have impact well beyond the data mining research community. The project has encompassed collaborations in both academia and industry. We applied our work in diverse disciplines including medicine, finance, meteorology, energy and manufacturing. Efforts of this research were disseminated via publications, software, invited talks, and conference presentations. Several students have participated in the project with varying degrees of involvement, including five graduate students, three undergraduate students, and one high school student. In terms of educational impact, the PI incorporated the research ideas from this project in her advanced graduate-level data mining class.
